case_name: Kantamani Venkata Narayana Sons v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 154 to 165 of 1966 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Appeals Nos. 117 to 128 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 154, to 165 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Appea

facts.text: M/s. Kantamani Venkata Narayana Sons is a Hindu undivided family assessed to tax on income derived principally from money-lending.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Kantamani Venkata Narayana Sons-hereinafter referred to as the assessee is a Hindu undivided family, which was assessed to tax on income derived principally from money--lending.

facts.text: In the course of proceedings for assessment of Motu Industries Ltd., the Income-tax Officer, Rajahmundry discovered a large accretion to the wealth of the assessee not disclosed in its assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of proceedings for assessment of a private limited companypany styled Motu Industries Ltd., the Incometax Officer, Rajahmundry discovered that there was a large accretion to the wealth of the assessee which had number been disclosed in proceedings for its assessment.

facts.text: On March 12, 1959, the Income-tax Officer issued a notice seeking to reopen the assessment for the year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: On March 12, 1959, the Income-tax Officer issued a numberice seeking to reopen the assessment for the year 1950-51. The assessee filed a return under protest.

facts.text: The assessee filed a return under protest for the 1950-51 assessment reopening.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed a return under protest. On March 14, 1960 the Income-tax Officer issued numberice of re-assessment for the year 1951-52, and on December 19, 1960, the Income-tax Officer intimated the reasons that had prompted him to issue the numberices of re-assessment.

facts.text: On March 14, 1960, the Income-tax Officer issued notice of re-assessment for the year 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: On March 14, 1960 the Income-tax Officer issued numberice of re-assessment for the year 1951-52, and on December 19, 1960, the Income-tax Officer intimated the reasons that had prompted him to issue the numberices of re-assessment.

facts.text: On December 19, 1960, the Income-tax Officer intimated the reasons for issuing the notices of re-assessment.

On March 24, 1962 the Income- tax Officer issued numberices under s. 34 for re-assessment of income of the assessee for the years 1940-41 to 1949-50.

facts.text: On March 24, 1962, the Income-tax Officer issued notices under s. 34 for re-assessment of income for the years 1940-41 to 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: On March 24, 1962 the Income- tax Officer issued numberices under s. 34 for re-assessment of income of the assessee for the years 1940-41 to 1949-50. The assessee then presented petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for writs of prohibition directing the Income-tax Officer to refrain from proceeding in pursuance of the numberices for the assessment years 1940-41 to 1949-50 and 1950-51 and 1951-52.

facts.text: The assessee presented petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for writs of prohibition against proceedings for assessment years 1940-41 to 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then presented petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for writs of prohibition directing the Income-tax Officer to refrain from proceeding in pursuance of the numberices for the assessment years 1940-41 to 1949-50 and 1950-51 and 1951-52.

facts.text: A single Judge of the High Court rejected the assessee's petitions.

anchor.surface_text: A single Judge of the High Court rejected the petitions and the order was companyfirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: The order rejecting the petitions was confirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the order was companyfirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court. The assessee has appealed with special leave.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Supreme Court with special leave.

facts.text: Scrutiny of money-lending statements filed by the assessee for years ended 31-3-50 and 31-3-51 revealed large investments in money-lending business.

anchor.surface_text: A scrutiny of the money-lending statements filed by the assessee for the years ended 31-3-50 and 31-3-51 revealed that there were large investments made by the assessee in his money-lending business in those two years.

facts.text: The assessee did not file balance sheets for the years ended 31-3-50, 31-3-51, or earlier assessment years.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee did number file balance sheets for the said two years, or for the earlier assessment years and companysequently it was number clear from the statements filed by him, how he companyld make heavy investments in money-lending business in those two years.

facts.text: In the year of account 1949-50, total investments in money-lending business increased by Rs. 1,33,000/- and in the following year by Rs. 49,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer also stated that in the year of account 1949-50 the total investments in money-lending business had increased by Rs. 1,33,000/- and in the following year by Rs. 49,000/-

facts.text: The assessee claimed growth in investments was due to cash balance from manager's share on partition with brothers and cash gifts from father-in-law, unsupported by evidence.

anchor.surface_text: and the plea of the assessee that growth in the investments of the assessee in those years was mainly due to the cash balance he by the manager out of his share received on partition between his and his brothers, and cash gifts from his father-in-law which were till then kept uninvested even in the money-lending business, was number supported by any evidence,

facts.text: The assessee suppressed account books for periods prior to April 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: that the assessee had suppressed the account books for the periods prior to April 1, 1949, and that the assessee had number produced the deed of partition relied upon.

facts.text: The assessee did not produce the deed of partition relied upon.

anchor.surface_text: and that the assessee had number produced the deed of partition relied upon. According to the Income-tax Officer, the net wealth of the family ,on April 1, 1937,

facts.text: Net wealth of the family on April 1, 1937, inclusive of investments in money-lending business was less than Rs. 50,000/-, with investments approximately Rs. 21,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: According to the Income-tax Officer, the net wealth of the family ,on April 1, 1937, inclusive of investments in the money-lending business was less than Rs. 50,000/- and the investments made by the assessee in money-lending business were approximately of the ,order of Rs. 21,000/-,

facts.text: Assessments on the family from 1937-38 till 1948-49 showed aggregate income of Rs. 30,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: that the assessments made on the family from 1937-38 till 1948-49 showed that the assessees aggregate income for those years was Rs. 30,000/- ,

facts.text: Taking into account manager's professional income and agricultural income, aggregate could not exceed Rs. one lakh for 1937-38 to 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: that taking into account the managers professional income and the agricultural income of the assessee, the aggregate companyld number exceed Rs. one lakh, and that possession of large wealth on April 1, 1949 which was number explained justified him in inferring that there was escapement assessment of huge income

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer had reason to believe that due to non-disclosure of material facts, income escaped assessment, as per affidavits accepted by the Court of First Instance.

anchor.surface_text: or in any event it had resulted in under-assessment on account of the failure of the assessee in number disclosing the material facts fully and truly for the assessment years 1940-41 to 1949-50. The averments made by the Income-tax Officer in his affidavit which have been accepted by the Court of First Instance, prima facie, establish that the Income-tax Officer had reason to believe

facts.text: The assessee produced account books and statements year after year before the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the assessee that year after year account books and statements of account were produced by the assessee before the Income-tax Officer, and the Income-tax Officer had companyputed to taxable income on the materials furnished,

facts.text: There was considerable increase since 1938 in investments in money-lending transactions and wealth of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavit of the Income-tax Officer it clearly appears that there had been companysiderable increase since 1938 in the investments in the money-lending transactions of the assessee and in the wealth of the assessee.

facts.text: The increase in wealth was wholly disproportionate to known sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer was number seeking to re- assess the income on a mere change of opinion. The increase in the wealth discovered was wholly disproportionate to the known sources of income of the assessee.

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 3, 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Appeals Nos. 117 to 128 of 1964. Ram Reddy and A. V. V. Nair, for the appellants  in all the appeals . V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Sachthey, for respondent  in all the appeals .
The assessee has appealed with special leave.

The assessee then presented petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for writs of prohibition directing the Income-tax Officer to refrain from proceeding in pursuance of the numberices for the assessment years 1940-41 to 1949-50 and 1950-51 and 1951-52.

On March 24, 1962 the Income- tax Officer issued numberices under s. 34 for re-assessment of income of the assessee for the years 1940-41 to 1949-50. The assessee then presented petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for writs of prohibition directing the Income-tax Officer to refrain from proceeding in pursuance of the numberices for the assessment years 1940-41 to 1949-50 and 1950-51 and 1951-52.

concepts.interpretation: Authorizes reassessment proceedings after specified period if conditions met; notice need not specify subclause.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: in pursuance of the numberices for the assessment years 1940-41 to 1949-50 and 1950-51 and 1951-52. A single Judge of the High Court rejected the pet

anchor.surface_text: If-  a  the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that by reason of the omission or failure on the part of an assessee to make a return of his income under section 22 for any year or to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year, income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment for that year, or have been under- assessed, or assessed at too low a rate, or  b  numberwithstanding that there has been numberomission or failure as mentioned in clause  a  on the part of the assessee, the Income-tax Officer has in companysequence of information in his possession reason to believe that income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment for any year, or have been under-assessed, or assessed at too low a rate, he may in cases falling under clause  a  at any time and in cases falling under clause  b  at the time within four years of the end of that year, serve on the assessee, a numberice companytaining all or any of the -requirements which may be included in a numberice under sub-section  2  of section 22 and may proceed to assess or re-assess such income, profits or gains

concepts.interpretation: Two conditions precedent: (1) reason to believe income escaped/under-assessed; (2) due to assessee's non-disclosure of material facts fully and truly. No time limit.

concepts.interpretation: Applies notwithstanding no omission by assessee, based on information in possession, limited to 4 years.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation Production before the Income-tax Officer of account books or other evidence from which material facts companyld with due diligence have been discovered by the Income- tax Officer will number necessarily amount to disclosure within the meaning of this section.

concepts.interpretation: Mere production of account books or evidence does not discharge duty of full and true disclosure; assessee must highlight material facts.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: 1 to 1949-50. The averments made by the Income-tax Officer in his affidavit which have been accepted by the Court of First Instance, prima facie, esta

anchor.surface_text: before the Income-tax Officer may issue a numberice under s. 34 1   a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, two companyditions precedent must companyexist the Income-tax Officer must have reason to believe  1  that income, profits or gains had been under-assessed, and  2  that such under assessment was due to number-disclosure of material facts by the assessee. The Court further held that where the Income-tax Officer has prima facie reasonable grounds for believing that there has been a number-disclosure of a primary material fact, that by itself gives him jurisdiction to issue a numberice under s. 34 of the Act, and the adequacy or otherwise of the grounds of such belief is number open to investigation by the Court.... the belief must be held in good  faithit cannot be merely a pretence. To put it differently it is open to the Court to examine the question whether the reasons for the belief have a rational companynection or a relevant bearing to the formation of the belief and are number extraneous or irrelevant to the purpose of the section.

concepts.interpretation: Formation of belief must be in good faith with rational connection between reasons and belief; court can challenge existence of belief or irrelevance/extraneousness, but not adequacy/sufficiency of grounds.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: in companysequence of information in his possession reason to believe that income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment

concepts.unlisted_description: Jurisdictional requirement for s.34 reassessment notice; objective element reviewable to limited extent

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the assessee that year after year account books and statements of account were produced by the assessee before the Income-tax Officer, and the Income-tax Officer had companyputed to taxable income on the materials furnished, numbercase for exercising the power of the Income- tax Officer under s. 34 was made out, since power to re- assess may number be exercised merely because on the same evidence the Income-tax Officer or his successor entertains a different opinion.

concepts.interpretation: Reassessment not permissible on mere change of opinion regarding same facts/materials previously considered.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Officer it clearly appears that there had been companysiderable increase since 1938 in the investments in the money-lending transactions of the asses

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibition on reopening based on revised view of same evidence

anchor.surface_text: From the mere production of the books of account it cannot be inferred that there had been full disclosure of the material facts necessary for the purpose of assessment. The terms of the Explanation are too plain to permit an argument being reasonably advanced, that the duty of the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts is discharged when he produces the books of account or other evidence which has a material bearing on the assessment. It is clearly implicit in the terms of ss. 23 and 34 of the Income-tax Act that the assessee is under a duty to disclose fully and truly material facts necessary for the assessment of the year, and that the duty is number discharged merely by the production of the books of accounts or other evidence. It is the duty of the assessee to bring to the numberice of the Income-tax Officer particular items in the books of account or portions of documents which are relevant.

concepts.interpretation: Assessee bears active duty to fully and truly disclose all material facts relevant to assessment, beyond mere production of books; must alert ITO to key items.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: at year after year account books and statements of account were produced by the assessee before the Income-tax Officer, and the Income-tax Officer had

issues.text: Whether the proceeding under s.34 is vitiated because the notice issued by the Income-tax Officer did not specifically refer to s.34(1)(a) or set out the clause under which it was issued.

anchor.surface_text: The notice issued by the Income-tax Officer did number specifically refer to s. 34 1  a  of the Income-tax Act it did number set out the clause under which it was issued. But on that account the proceeding under s 34 is -not vitiated. It was held by the Calcutta Sup.C.1.166-18 High Court in P. R. Mukherj

issues.text: Whether, before issuing notice under s.34(1)(a), the two conditions precedent existed: (1) Income-tax Officer had reason to believe income had escaped assessment/under-assessed, and (2) such escapement was due to assessee's omission or failure to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for assessment.

anchor.surface_text: before the Income-tax Officer may issue a numberice under s. 34 1   a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, two companyditions precedent must companyexist the Income-tax Officer must have reason to believe  1  that income, profits or gains had been under-assessed, and  2  that such under assessment was due to number-disclosure of material facts by the assessee. The Court further held that where the Income-tax Officer has prima facie reasonable grounds for believing that there has been a number-disclosure of a primary material fact, that by itself gives him jurisdiction to issue a numberice under s. 34 of the Act, and the adequacy or otherwise of the grounds of such belief is number open to investigation by the Court.... the belief must be held in good  faithit cannot be merely a pretence.

issues.text: Whether power to reassess under s.34 may be exercised merely because the Income-tax Officer or his successor entertains a different opinion on the same evidence previously considered.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the assessee that year after year account books and statements of account were produced by the assessee before the Income-tax Officer, and the Income-tax Officer had companyputed to taxable income on the materials furnished, numbercase for exercising the power of the Income- tax Officer under s. 34 was made out, since power to re- assess may number be exercised merely because on the same evidence the Income-tax Officer or his successor entertains a different opinion.

issues.text: Whether the assessee's mere production of account books or other evidence before the Income-tax Officer amounts to full and true disclosure of all material facts necessary for assessment, discharging the duty under s.34.

anchor.surface_text: From the mere production of the books of account it cannot be inferred that there had been full disclosure of the material facts necessary for the purpose of assessment. The terms of the Explanation are too plain to permit an argument being reasonably advanced, that the duty of the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts is discharged when he produces the books of account or other evidence which has a material bearing on the assessment. It is clearly implicit in the terms of ss. 23 and 34 of the Income-tax Act that the assessee is under a duty to disclose fully and truly material facts necessary for the assessment of the year, and that the duty is number discharged merely by the production of the books of accounts or other evidence.

arguments.claim: The proceeding under s.34 is vitiated because the notice issued by the Income-tax Officer did not specifically refer to s.34(1)(a) or set out the clause under which it was issued.

anchor.surface_text: The notice issued by the Income-tax Officer did number specifically refer to s. 34 1  a  of the Income-tax Act it did number set out the clause under which it was issued. But on that account the proceeding under s 34 is -not vitiated. It was held by the Calcutta Sup.C.1.166-18 High Court in P. R. Mukherj

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice under s.22(2) is main notice; s.34 authorizes it; precedent from Calcutta HC in P.R. Mukherjee v. CIT holds specification not necessary.

arguments.claim: Notice under s.34 need not specify clause (a) or (b); main notice is under s.22(2), s.34 merely authorizes it.

anchor.surface_text: But on that account the proceeding under s 34 is -not vitiated. It was held by the Calcutta Sup.C.1.166-18 High Court in P. R. Mukherjee v. Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal 1 , that it is number necessary or imperative that a numberice -under s. 34 must specify under which of the two clauses-cl.  a an cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s. 34, the numberice is issued. The main numberice to be issued in a case under s. 34 is the numberice under s. 22 2 , and s. 34 merely authorises the issue of such a numberice.

arguments.claim: Before issuing notice under s.34(1)(a), two conditions precedent must exist: (1) ITO has reason to believe income escaped/under-assessed; (2) due to assessee's omission/failure to disclose fully/truly all material facts.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Calcutta Discount Company Ltd. v. Income-tax officer, Companies District 1 and Another 1  observed that before the Income-tax Officer may issue a numberice under s. 34 1   a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, two companyditions precedent must companyexist the Income-tax Officer must have reason to believe  1  that income, profits or gains had been under-assessed, and  2  that such under assessment was due to number-disclosure of material facts by the assessee. The Court further held that where the Income-tax Officer has prima facie reasonable grounds for believing that there has been a number-disclosure of a primary material fact, that by itself gives him jurisdiction to issue a numberice under s. 34 of the Act, and the adequacy or otherwise of the grounds of such belief is number open to investigation by the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Averments in ITO's affidavit detailing unexplained investments, suppressed books, disproportionate wealth growth accepted by lower court as prima facie establishing both conditions precedent under s.34(1)(a).

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that no case for exercising power under s.34 was made out because it amounts to mere change of opinion on the same evidence; the increase in wealth was wholly disproportionate to known sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavit of the Income-tax Officer it clearly appears that there had been companysiderable increase since 1938 in the investments in the money-lending transactions of the assessee and in the wealth of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit shows considerable increase in investments and wealth since 1938 disproportionate to known income sources; prima facie non-disclosure, not mere change of opinion.

holdings.text: From the mere production of the books of account it cannot be inferred that there had been full disclosure of the material facts necessary for the purpose of assessment; the duty of the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts is not discharged merely by the production of the books of account or other evidence.

anchor.surface_text: From the mere production of the books of account it cannot be inferred that there had been full disclosure of the material facts necessary for the purpose of assessment. The terms of the Explanation are too plain to permit an argument being reasonably advanced, that the duty of the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts is discharged when he produces the books of account or other evidence which has a material bearing on the assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain terms of Explanation to s.34; implicit in ss.23 and 34 that assessee must disclose fully and truly, including drawing attention to particular relevant items in books.

holdings.text: It is the duty of the assessee to bring to the notice of the Income-tax Officer particular items in the books of account or portions of documents which are relevant; even if the Income-tax Officer could have discovered the truth with due diligence from produced books, he is not precluded from exercising power under s.34.

anchor.surface_text: It is clearly implicit in the terms of ss. 23 and 34 of the Income-tax Act that the assessee is under a duty to disclose fully and truly material facts necessary for the assessment of the year, and that the duty is number discharged merely by the production of the books of accounts or other evidence. It is the duty of the assessee to bring to the numberice of the Income-tax Officer particular items in the books of account or portions of documents which are relevant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee's active duty under ss.23 & 34 goes beyond production; Explanation clarifies mere production insufficient even if diligence could reveal facts.

holdings.text: The belief of the Income-tax Officer under s.34 must be held in good faith with rational connection or relevant bearing between reasons and belief; court may examine existence of belief and relevance of reasons but not their adequacy or sufficiency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and applies precedents from Calcutta Discount Co. and S. Narayanappa on scope of judicial review of 'reason to believe'.

precedents.citation: P. R. Mukherjee v. Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: P. R. Mukherjee v. Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal 1 , that it is number necessary or imperative that a numberice -under s. 34 must specify under which of the two clauses-cl.  a an cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s. 34, the numberice is issued.

precedents.case_name: P. R. Mukherjee v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: It is not necessary or imperative that a notice under s. 34 must specify under which of the two clauses (cl. (a) and cl. (b)) of sub-s. (1) of s. 34 the notice is issued.

precedents.citation: Calcutta Discount Company Ltd. v. Income-tax officer, Companies District 1 and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: Calcutta Discount Company Ltd. v. Income-tax officer, Companies District 1 and Another 1  observed that before the Income-tax Officer may issue a numberice under s. 34 1   a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, two companyditions precedent must companyexist the Income-tax Officer must have reason to believe  1  that income, profits or gains had been under-assessed, and  2  that such under assessment was due to number-disclosure of material facts by the assessee.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Discount Company Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Companies District I and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: Before issuing notice under s. 34(1)(a), ITO must have reason to believe (1) income under-assessed and (2) due to non-disclosure of material facts by assessee; prima facie grounds suffice, adequacy not for court.

precedents.citation: S. Narayanappa Others v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bangalore, 2

anchor.surface_text: S. Narayanappa Others v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bangalore, 2  Ramaswami J., speaking for the Court observed . . . the legal position is that if there are in fact some reasonable grounds for the Income-tax Officer to believe that there had been any number-disclosure as regards any fact, which companyld have a material bearing on the question of under-assessment that would be sufficient to give jurisdiction to the Income- tax Officer to issue the numberice under s. 34.

precedents.case_name: S. Narayanappa and Others v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bangalore
precedents.cited_proposition: Reasonable grounds for ITO's belief in non-disclosure of material facts sufficient for jurisdiction under s.34; court examines existence and rational connection of belief, not sufficiency.

From the mere production of the books of account it cannot be inferred that there had been full disclosure of the material facts necessary for the purpose of assessment. The terms of the Explanation are too plain to permit an argument being reasonably advanced, that the duty of the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts is discharged when he produces the books of account or other evidence which has a material bearing on the assessment.
